title: Government Disputes TransMilenio Fare Hike Amidst Labor Market Adjustments
subtitle: Report automatically generated on 2026-01-13 by the Trade Section, EU Delegation to Colombia
summary: The government is challenging a TransMilenio fare increase in Bogotá, arguing it is not sufficiently justified by the minimum wage hike [[REF:624d95c5-12c4-4917-a36b-c79ccf14d9b8]][[REF:79edf6bf-c48f-4d93-8dff-cb641361151d]]. Simultaneously, the Colombian labor market is navigating the effects of a significant 23% minimum wage increase, prompting internal adjustments and potential challenges for businesses [[REF:2a637c03-7833-42dd-98a4-a312ebaa8211]]. Meanwhile, global economic trends show a decrease in OECD inflation to 3.9% in November, primarily driven by food prices [[REF:5b6421ce-5129-49fb-a4ff-6d60407f595e]].

sections.title: Economic Policy and Labor Market Dynamics
sections.body: The Colombian government has expressed strong reservations about the recent 10.9% increase in TransMilenio fares in Bogotá, arguing that the 23% rise in the minimum wage does not sufficiently justify the transportation fare hike [[REF:624d95c5-12c4-4917-a36b-c79ccf14d9b8]][[REF:79edf6bf-c48f-4d93-8dff-cb641361151d]]. The Ministry of Transportation has requested a detailed technical analysis to support the decision [[REF:79edf6bf-c48f-4d93-8dff-cb641361151d]]. This comes as the broader Colombian labor market is experiencing significant shifts. A substantial 23% increase in the minimum wage at the start of 2026 is leading to internal adjustments and potentially challenging decisions for both companies and workers [[REF:2a637c03-7833-42dd-98a4-a312ebaa8211]]. Experts anticipate these adjustments will ripple throughout the entire salary structure [[REF:2a637c03-7833-42dd-98a4-a312ebaa8211]].

sections.title: Inflation Trends and Global Economic Indicators
sections.body: Globally, inflation within the OECD countries saw a decrease, standing at 3.9% in November [[REF:5b6421ce-5129-49fb-a4ff-6d60407f595e]]. This reduction is largely attributed to a decline in food prices, which fell to 4% in November, a full percentage point lower than in September [[REF:5b6421ce-5129-49fb-a4ff-6d60407f595e]]. Conversely, energy prices experienced a slight increase, rising to 3.5% in November from 3.1% in September [[REF:5b6421ce-5129-49fb-a4ff-6d60407f595e]]. Costa Rica remains the only OECD member with negative inflation, recorded at -0.4% in November, consistent with October levels [[REF:5b6421ce-5129-49fb-a4ff-6d60407f595e]]. In contrast, coffee, tea, cocoa, sweets, and meat prices saw significant increases in 2025, contributing over 50% to the annual food inflation rate, with climate change identified as a major factor [[REF:a4d13076-a52d-4e41-8a01-46275a15dc5d]].

sections.title: Political and Security Developments
sections.body: President Gustavo Petro issued a strong warning to the ELN, stating that if the group does not join the peace process and withdraw from Venezuela, his government will pursue joint military operations with Venezuela [[REF:ad721b43-7f12-47c6-afc5-9771ceafaa53]]. This statement comes amidst discussions on border security and international cooperation, with Petro also convening the Advisory Commission on Foreign Relations to discuss matters concerning Venezuela and the United States [[REF:91f75218-2d5b-4b23-8397-ed4fb08b6a2f]][[REF:47372fbd-370a-4c07-9043-b62ff5e25bda]]. The ELN has broken its silence, proposing a 'national agreement' in response to potential joint actions by the US and Colombia [[REF:a30943d0-d70d-4226-a3db-24f3a6b0957b]]. However, this proposal has faced criticism, with Sergio Fajardo labeling it an attempt to manipulate elections [[REF:ddb3d334-af5b-40e3-9c84-03943028b8cd]]. The Justice Minister has suspended the transfer of criminal gang leaders to Barranquilla, citing social pressure and conflicting statements, a move that follows controversy and public debate [[REF:370895e7-1af9-42f4-844d-b52dac4bdf91]][[REF:af42e6d9-a1e8-40a5-aedc-c62d233c1ab8]].

sections.title: Trade and International Relations
sections.body: The imposition of a 25% tariff by Donald Trump on Iran's partners is prompting Latin American governments, including Colombia, to re-evaluate their traditional export routes and partnerships [[REF:b099a7a8-0b1f-4bb7-96ed-4725bc442c8b]]. This development necessitates a strategic reassessment of international trade relationships.

sections.title: Fiscal and Regulatory Changes
sections.body: Colombia's Labor Reform is set to introduce changes in 2026 regarding the payment of severance interest, aiming to improve financial planning for both employees and companies [[REF:c0ca46c7-f938-4e34-9317-bff972c5d3fa]]. Additionally, new regulations will impact how pensions are taxed, with specific implications for pensioners [[REF:f1cd3c56-20d2-4973-b71d-fd6638f88236]].
